content: <@456226577798135808> I agree with you and we should be cognizant to not let these breakout sessions turn into tons of calls. What is your ideal formats or mediums for async comms? If it isn't multiple sub-rooms per topic what is it?

author: sky.cactus
content: I would love to see **more people discussing things in public chat rooms**.  I'm a *huge* fan of the Turbo Geth discord server because it appears *all* of their dev communication is done via their channel so I can listen in casually.  Also, because of this it is really easy to get an answer/feedback from their team because they are very active in Discord.

author: sky.cactus
content: For the broader core dev community, I have often struggled to get feedback from them on changes (e.g., 1559, 2718, etc.) outside of a call.  It ***feels* like the ACD calls are the only time that some of the core devs will look** at anything outside whatever it is they are working on for the rest of the week.

author: sky.cactus
content: Often times right before (when people are prepping) or right after a call where I bring up something that has been open for discussion on Magicians forum/Discord for weeks or months there will be a sudden flurry of questions and answers that all could have been answered at any time in the weeks leading up to the call, which ***implies*** that many people are seeing the issue for the first time at/around the ACD call.

author: sky.cactus
content: Unfortunately, this results in **a lot of conversations that could happen outside of the call being forced into the call because it seems to be the only way to get core dev attention** sometimes.

author: sky.cactus
content: (note: I have seen this pattern not just for stuff I'm championing, but also stuff others are championing)

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't have a great solution to this as I definitely don't think us champions have any place telling core devs how to manage their time.  However, I *do* think it would be valuable to get more eyes/feedback on things outside of the calls so the calls can focus on specific issues that need a call for resolution.

author: Deleted User
content: <@!191378736254287874> There is no ideal medium that fits everybody. It is a balancing act, of course. And it is dynamic - we often move from one place to another. Also depends on what priorities of the groups are. For example, we used to do a lot of calls in turbo-geth team to discuss Pull requests before they are merged. It was great for education and I got a lot of positive feedback about that. But it was hard for me, because things moved too slowly. So I had to drop most of them and force communication mostly on Discord. There are things we've gained and thing we've lost. We've gained some development cadence. But people in the team started to be less aware of other people's context. I had to compensate for that by having to be on top of everything, but I prefer this to having calls, because it is asynchronous and fitted better my lifestyle (especially when schools were closed and I could not plan my days in advance)

author: Deleted User

author: holiman
content:
>  I have been calling for pauses and moratoriums for ages, but noone seems to be taking me seriously on that, even core developers themselves [...] And ACD is being "too soft" and "crowd pleasing" not to prioritise harde

I totally agree with this, but we have different priorities. I personally prioritize 2929 very highly, which I think you don't (?). I don't really care about subroutines, and I'm scared of bls-precompiles (and would personally rather reject them). I see the yolov1 / yolov2 definitions as the best way to drive them forward. I talked to <@!329594653097721856> yesterday; at OE, they don't want to implement anything that isn't already "definite" for Berlin. But IMO nothing is definite for Berlin, it's what we make of it. I see the decision process as a spiral between spec<->test, eventually leading up to well-tested implementations that are ready for mainnet. And the decision to include something becomes "definite" when it's eventually slated for a particular blocknumber.

author: holiman
content: Maybe we (personally) should be clearer about what we _really_ think about EIPs. Basically rate them on a scale: " Very much dislike ... Meh ... Very much approve"

author: holiman
content: I think it's problematic that it's so easy to use the  "disagreement through silence, and hope for it to pass by"  approach... that's what makes things get accepted as in "well, nobody seems to object here..."

author: sky.cactus
content: As both an EIP editor and an EIP champion, it would be great to get more clear feedback from core devs on their current sentiment, along with *why* they hold that sentiment.

author: holiman
content: And I guess a problem for you as EIP author is that the only ones who will give you feedback on a moderately complicated proposal are the ones who are already in favour of it, those who don't agree with it are less likely to spend X hours diving into it

author: sky.cactus
content: I *try* to address that by splitting EIPs up as much as possible into byte sized chunks, but sometimes that isn't possible, and sometimes I fail at it, and sometimes monolithic is necessary for some reason.

author: holiman
content: As for "2718", I personally just want to have access lists in, and if 2718 is the way to do that, well.... However, it seems like a very large proposal for something which, ostensibly, shouldn't need such large changes

author: sky.cactus
content: 2718 is because it sure would be nice to not introduce technical debt every time we want to add something like 155 (chain ID) or 2930 (access lists).

author: sky.cactus
content: It isn't strictly necessary, but it makes it so we *can* do stuff like 2930 without introducing technical debt that we'll be stuck paying for years.
